timeline.message: HBASE-24321 - Add writable MinVersions and read-only Scan to coproc ScanOptions

timeline.bodyText: The Scan constructor throws IOE now?? Not an issue for this patch, though
timeline.author: apurtell

replies.bodyText: Looks like the copy constructor for Scan has thrown IOException back since 2009, but the current code does not actually contain anything that throws it. Since I assume changing the signature is more trouble than it's worth, I just had to rethrow from the CustomizedScanInfoBuilder constructor and getScan() methods.
replies.author: gjacoby126

replies.bodyText: Let's just catch the IOException in the code here and then throw an AssertionError to indicate this should not happen, and we can filed another issue to remove the IOException from throws.
replies.author: Apache9

timeline.bodyText: Changes made on the returned scan object will be effective and visible beyond the caller. Clone and return?
timeline.author: apurtell

replies.bodyText: I didn't check to see how much of Scan is immutable...
replies.author: apurtell

replies.bodyText: Scan is mostly mutable, I think. That's a good point -- the clone in the constructor will prevent changes from executing, but a caller could still mess up the state for future callers. I'll clone in the getter.
replies.author: gjacoby126

timeline.author: apurtell

timeline.message: HBASE-24321 - Add writable MinVersions and read-only Scan to coproc ScanOptions

timeline.bodyText: I think this class is only used to test whether a specific CP method has been called? What is this used for?
timeline.author: Apache9

replies.bodyText: See TestRegionCoprocessorHost. It's used to test that the scanner coproc hooks are wired up correctly and can alter a ScanInfo.
replies.author: gjacoby126

replies.bodyText: OK, the rebuild of the ScanInfo is done in RegionCoprocessorHost, I used to thought it is done in HStore on some other places.
replies.author: Apache9

timeline.bodyText: Is this method still referenced? Just remove it?
timeline.author: Apache9

replies.bodyText: It was used by a few tests: TestCompaction, TestDefaultCompaction, TestMajorCompaction.
replies.author: gjacoby126

timeline.bodyText:
Please add a comment to say that the returned Scan object is only for reading, changing it will have no effect to the actual scan operation.
And please modify the javadoc of this class to indicate that now we can also change min versions?
timeline.author: Apache9

timeline.message: HBASE-24321 - Add writable MinVersions and read-only Scan to coproc ScanOptions
HBASE-24321 - Add writable MinVersions and read-only Scan to coproc ScanOptions

timeline.bodyText:
The comment is a bit confusing as you are free to call the modification methods of the returned Scan object? So it is not 'read only'.
Maybe better with "The returned Scan object is just a copy, modifying it will have no effect, so treat it as read-only."
Of course I'm not a native English speaker, so feel free to use your own word. Just show the meaning that 'you can modify, but no effect, so please do not modify'.
timeline.author: Apache9

timeline.message: HBASE-24321 - Add writable MinVersions and read-only Scan to coproc ScanOptions

timeline.bodyText: Might be good at some point to have an unmodifiable subclass or wrapper of Scan, so that any modification would cause an error. (not in this PR, though)
timeline.author: lhofhansl

replies.bodyText: +1 to Immutable Scan wrapper with unmodifiable getters
replies.author: virajjasani

replies.bodyText: +1..  That was something came to my mind too while reading the Jira desc. :-)
replies.author: anoopsjohn

replies.bodyText: Already the scan object been cloned while setting in this class..  Every time with get also we need to clone?
replies.author: anoopsjohn

replies.bodyText: @anoopsjohn  In the original draft it was only cloned in the constructor. @apurtell pointed out that that meant that one coproc override could call getScan(), call a setter on the Scan, and that a subsequent override would see the modified Scan, so he asked me to fix that.
replies.author: gjacoby126

replies.bodyText: Ok.  An ImmutableScan would have helped. Fine. As long as we dont have lets do this.
replies.author: anoopsjohn
